questions.text: Which of the following stains is used to study fungal morphology in tissue sections?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PAS (Periodic Acid-Schiff) stain is used to study fungal morphology in tissue sections by highlighting the polysaccharides in the fungal cell walls, making them appear magenta.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with a rough, scaly lesion on his sun-exposed forearm. The lesion is suspected to be precancerous having a characteristic histopathology finding of persistent nucleus in stratum corneum. What is the most likely condition associated with the above clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Actinic keratoses

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Parakeratosis most frequently occurs in actinic keratoses, which are precancerous lesions caused by chronic sun exposure and characterized by rough, scaly patches on sun-exposed skin.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with multiple painful blisters on her skin. The blisters are filled with clear fluid, and a Tzanck smear is performed on one of the lesions. The smear shows specific cytological findings that help in diagnosing her condition. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on a Tzanck smear of her lesions?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acantholysis is a characteristic finding on a Tzanck smear from a bullous lesion, indicative of conditions such as pemphigus vulgaris.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with multiple, painful blisters on her skin. On physical examination, you notice flaccid bullae and erosions primarily on her trunk and extremities. A biopsy of one of the lesions is performed, revealing loss of cohesion between keratinocytes. Which of the following layers is primarily involved in this pathology?

options.label: C
options.text: In all the layers of Skin

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Epidermis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acantholysis is the loss of cohesion between keratinocytes primarily seen in the epidermis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of progressive hair thinning and hair loss, which is diagnosed as androgenic alopecia. The physician discusses various treatment options and medications with the patient. Which of the following is contraindicated in the treatment of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Testosterone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Testosterone is contraindicated in the treatment of androgenic alopecia as it can worsen hair loss by increasing DHT levels. Treatments such as cyproterone acetate (in women), finasteride, and minoxidil are used to manage androgenic alopecia by either blocking androgens or promoting hair growth.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with patches of hair loss on her scalp. On examination, the areas of hair loss appear smooth and shiny with evidence of scarring. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with cicatricial alopecia in this age group?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cicatricial alopecia is seen in discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE), an autoimmune condition that causes permanent hair loss and scarring due to the destruction of hair follicles.

questions.text: A patient presents with a characteristic nail abnormality where the proximal nail fold extends forward and adheres to the nail bed, leading to the loss of the normal nail structure. What condition is this nail abnormality characteristically seen in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lichen planus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pterygium of the nail is characteristically seen in lichen planus, where the proximal nail fold advances over the nail bed, causing scarring and nail destruction.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is WRONG?

options.label: D
options.text: Pterygium of nails in Lichen Planus

questions.correct_answer: A. Koilonychia in Vit B₁ deficiency
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Koilonychia in Vit B₁ deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Koilonychia is associated with iron deficiency anemia, not Vitamin B₁ deficiency. Onycholysis is commonly seen in psoriasis, Mees lines are indicative of arsenic poisoning, and pterygium of the nails can occur in lichen planus.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with severe, painful nodules and cysts on his face and upper back. He reports that over-the-counter treatments have been ineffective. The dermatologist diagnoses him with nodulocystic acne and recommends the most appropriate treatment to address his condition. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for the above discussed clinical condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 13-cis Retinoic Acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 13-cis Retinoic Acid (isotretinoin) is the treatment of choice for nodulocystic acne due to its effectiveness in reducing sebaceous gland activity and promoting long-term remission.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the clinic with concerns about small, painless, pale yellowish spots on the inner surface of his lips and the buccal mucosa. He reports that they have been present for several years without any changes. On examination, these spots are found to be asymptomatic and consistent with his description. What are these spots most likely to represent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ectopic sebaceous glands

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fordyce spots are ectopic sebaceous glands, appearing as small, painless, pale yellow or white spots on mucosal surfaces.

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple erythematous annular lesions with a peripheral collarette of scales arranged predominantly over the trunk. Considering the clinical presentation and distribution of the lesions. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pityriasis rosea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pityriasis rosea is characterized by multiple erythematous annular lesions with a peripheral collarette of scales, arranged predominantly over the trunk, often following the pattern of skin tension lines.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with well-demarcated, red, scaly plaques on her elbows and knees. She has a known history of psoriasis. The physician reviews common and uncommon characteristics of psoriasis to provide patient education. Which of the following statements about this condition is NOT true?

options.label: A
options.text: Head, neck, and face are not involved

options.label: B
options.text: Arthritis is seen in 5% of cases

options.label: C
options.text: Neutrophilic microabscesses are seen in lesions

options.label: D
options.text: Non-scaly, red lesions are seen in inframammary and natal regions.

questions.correct_answer: A. Head, neck, and face are not involved
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Head, neck, and face are not involved

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Psoriasis can involve the head, neck, and face, and is not limited to other body areas. It can also present with psoriatic arthritis in a significant proportion of patients and typically features neutrophilic microabscesses in its lesions. Non-scaly, red lesions can be seen in skin folds such as the inframammary and natal regions.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a known history of psoriasis presents to the dermatology clinic for a routine follow-up. During the visit, she asks about the various sites of involvement in psoriasis and which areas are LEAST likely to be affected. Which of the following is the LEAST common site of involvement in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) CNS involvement

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The least common site of involvement in psoriasis is the central nervous system (CNS), as psoriasis primarily affects the skin, nails, and joints.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with widespread, painful, and erythematous pustules on her body. She reports feeling unwell with fever and chills. A biopsy confirms the diagnosis of pustular psoriasis. You are considering the most effective treatment option to manage her condition. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acitretin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acitretin is the treatment of choice for pustular psoriasis due to its effectiveness in reducing inflammation and normalizing skin cell growth.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of persistent, painful lesions in her mouth. On examination, you notice white, lace-like patches on the buccal mucosa. She also mentions occasional itchy, purplish, flat-topped bumps on her wrists. What is the most likely diagnosis of this clinical scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lichen Planus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lichen planus is associated with characteristic oral lesions, presenting as white, lace-like patches on the mucous membranes.

questions.text: A newborn baby from a non-consanguineous marriage develops erosions and blisters in areas where the mother handles the child, including the perioral areas. Extensive denudation is noted. There is a history of a sibling who died with a similar presentation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Epidermolysis Bullosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Epidermolysis Bullosa is a genetic condition that causes the skin to be extremely fragile and prone to blistering and erosion with minor trauma or friction, consistent with the presentation of the newborn in this scenario.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with severely itchy papulovesicular lesions on the extremities, knees, elbows, and buttocks for one year. Direct immunofluorescence staining of the lesions shows IgA deposition at the dermoepidermal junction. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dermatitis herpetiformis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dermatitis herpetiformis is characterized by severely itchy papulovesicular lesions on extensor surfaces and the presence of IgA deposition at the dermoepidermal junction on direct immunofluorescence staining.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic with painful ulcers on her palate and multiple skin blisters. She reports that the blisters are fragile and easily rupture. The presence of both mucosal and skin lesions prompts a specific differential diagnosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pemphigus vulgaris

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pemphigus vulgaris is most likely the diagnosis in a young adult with both palatal ulcers and fragile skin blisters, given its characteristic presentation involving both mucosal and cutaneous lesions.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with blistering lesions on his skin that developed shortly after starting a new medication for hypertension. He denies any previous history of similar lesions. A biopsy and immunofluorescence study confirm the diagnosis of pemphigus. Which of the following medications is LEAST likely to be associated with drug-induced pemphigus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Penicillin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Penicillin is least likely to be associated with drug-induced pemphigus, whereas medications like phenolphthalein, frusemide, and iodine have been linked to this condition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with a variety of skin lesions. Considering his clinical history and symptoms, the physician suspects leprosy. The physician reviews the common types of skin lesions associated with leprosy to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following lesions is LEAST likely to be seen in leprosy?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vesicles are not characteristic lesions of leprosy, which more commonly presents with erythematous macules, hypopigmented patches, and both flat and raised patches.

questions.text: Which of the following types of leprosy is most likely associated with a negative skin smear report?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Neuritic type leprosy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neuritic type leprosy is most likely associated with negative skin smear reports due to its primary involvement of peripheral nerves and absent skin involvement.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the clinic with hypopigmented skin lesions and a loss of sensation in the affected areas. The physician suspects leprosy and decides to perform a skin biopsy to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following findings is characteristic of a skin biopsy in leprosy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Any of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Skin biopsies in leprosy can show a variety of findings, including periappendageal bacilli, periappendageal lymphocytosis, and perivascular lymphocytosis, reflecting the immune response and bacterial presence.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman being treated for leprosy presents to the dermatology clinic with concerns about new skin changes. She reports that her skin has developed dark pigmentation and a texture resembling ichthyosis. You review her medication history to identify the likely cause of these side effects. Which of the following medications is most likely associated with skin pigmentation and ichthyosis-like side effects?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Clofazimine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clofazimine, used in the treatment of leprosy, is most likely associated with skin pigmentation and ichthyosis-like side effects.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with a history of leprosy presents to the clinic with severe pain, redness, and swelling in his right ulnar nerve. He is diagnosed with acute neuritis associated with Lepra Type I (reversal) reaction. You are considering the appropriate treatment options to manage his symptoms and prevent further nerve damage. Which of the following is NOT a recommended treatment for the above discussed clinical case scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thalidomide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thalidomide is not used in the treatment of Type I Lepra reactions; the focus should be on steroids for inflammation and incision and drainage if necessary.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is LEAST likely to be caused by Staphylococcus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Erysipelas

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Erysipelas is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes, while conditions such as impetigo, ecthyma, and scalded skin syndrome can be caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the clinic with multiple draining sinuses on his jawline. He reports a history of dental infections and poor oral hygiene. Upon examination, the sinuses are found to be discharging pus containing sulfur granules. You suspect a bacterial infection as the underlying cause. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with discharging sinuses?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Actinomycosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Discharging sinuses are characteristic of actinomycosis, a bacterial infection often following dental infections or trauma, and presenting with pus containing sulfur granules.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with a skin condition characterized by small, Papular eruptions. He has a history of tuberculosis and the lesions are found to be associated with an underlying tuberculous infection. In which of the following conditions are Tuberculids seen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lichen scrofulosorum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tuberculids, such as lichen scrofulosorum, are hypersensitivity reactions to Mycobacterium tuberculosis or its antigens, and are seen in individuals with underlying tuberculosis. Lichen scrofulosorum is characterized by small, grouped papules and is a specific form of Tuberculids.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with a chronic, ulcerated lesion on his neck. He has a history of tuberculosis, and physical examination reveals enlarged, matted cervical lymph nodes with draining sinuses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Scrofuloderma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Scrofuloderma is cutaneous tuberculosis secondary to underlying tissue involvement, such as infected lymph nodes, bones, or joints, leading to chronic ulceration and sinus formation.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with multiple anogenital warts, and the biopsy reveals squamous atypia. Among the various human papillomavirus types, which ones are classified as high-risk?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) HPV 18

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HPV 18 is classified as a high-risk type and is associated with a higher risk of developing anogenital cancers.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with alopecia, a boggy scalp swelling, and easily pluckable hair. What is the next step in establishing a diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) KOH smear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A KOH smear is the next step in establishing the diagnosis of tinea capitis in a child presenting with alopecia, boggy scalp swelling, and easily pluckable hair, as it provides a rapid and effective method for identifying fungal elements.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of discolored and thickened toenails. She reports that her nails have become brittle and are separating from the nail bed. You suspect a fungal infection. Which of the following structures is primarily affected by the fungal infection of nails?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Nail plate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tinea unguium (onychomycosis) primarily affects the nail plate, leading to discoloration, thickening, and separation of the nail from the nail bed.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient from Jaipur presents with an erythematous lesion on the cheek with central crusting. Considering the geographic location and clinical presentation, What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cutaneous leishmaniasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cutaneous leishmaniasis is the likely diagnosis for a 20-year-old male from Jaipur presenting with an erythematous lesion on the cheek with central crusting, given the geographic prevalence and typical clinical presentation of the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is treated with permethrin?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Scabies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Permethrin is used in the treatment of scabies, a skin infestation caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the clinic with urethral discharge. The physician decides to use syndromic management to treat the underlying infections responsible for the discharge. Which of the following pairs of pathogens should be targeted in the syndromic management of urethral discharge?
questions.correct_answer: C. Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The syndromic management of urethral discharge includes treatment for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis, as these are the primary pathogens responsible for causing urethral discharge in sexually active individuals.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with a painless ulcer on his genital area. The physician suspects syphilis and discusses the diagnostic and immunological aspects of the disease with the patient. Which of the following statements is NOT true about this STD?

options.label: A
options.text: VDRL is sensitive but NOT specific

options.label: D
options.text: Treponema pallidum when inoculated in rabbit produces progressive disease

questions.correct_answer: B. Infection leads to lifelong immunity
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Infection leads to lifelong immunity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Syphilis infection does not lead to lifelong immunity, and individuals can be re-infected.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a ulcer on her genital area. She reports recent unprotected sexual intercourse. On examination, you also note the presence of inguinal lymphadenopathy. Based on her clinical presentation, you are considering various sexually transmitted infections as the potential cause. Which of the following conditions is NOT typically associated with lymphadenopathy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Donovanosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inguinal Lymphadenopathy is not typically seen in donovanosis (granuloma inguinale), whereas it is commonly associated with LGV, primary syphilis, and chancroid.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic with painful, swollen lymph nodes in the groin area. Over the past few weeks, these nodes have developed into buboes with multiple sinuses that are now discharging pus. He also reports a recent history of unprotected sexual intercourse. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with buboes with multiple sinuses discharging into inguinal lymph nodes?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) LGV (Lymphogranuloma Venereum)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ LGV (Lymphogranuloma Venereum) is associated with buboes with multiple sinuses discharging into inguinal lymph nodes.

questions.text: Which type of syphilis is associated with primary bullous lesions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Congenital

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary bullous lesions are seen in congenital syphilis, not in primary, secondary, or tertiary syphilis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with a history of recurrent skin rashes. The dermatologist decides to perform a patch test to identify any potential allergens causing her symptoms. When should the patch test be read for accurate results?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2 days

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A patch test is typically read at 48 hours (2 days) after application, with a possible additional reading at 72-96 hours to detect delayed hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with a history of recurrent episodes of dermatitis. He mentions that his symptoms often flare up after being outdoors, particularly in rural areas. The dermatologist suspects an airborne allergen as the cause. What is the commonest cause of airborne dermatitis in India?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Parthenium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The commonest cause of airborne dermatitis in India is Parthenium, a widespread weed that releases allergens into the air, leading to dermatitis in sensitized individuals.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents to the clinic with multiple hypopigmented scaly patches on the cheek. The patch has no associated sensory loss. There is no history of any other significant symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pityriasis alba

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pityriasis alba is a common cause of hypopigmented scaly patches on the face in children, typically without sensory loss or other significant symptoms.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl presents with light brown pigmentation over the malar eminences. Considering the clinical presentation and patient demographics, What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Melasma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Melasma is the likely diagnosis for a 19-year-old girl presenting with light brown pigmentation over the malar eminences, given its typical presentation and demographic prevalence.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl presents with arthritis and a photosensitive rash on her cheeks. Considering the clinical presentation of arthritis and photosensitivity, What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) SLE

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SLE is the likely diagnosis for a 19-year-old girl presenting with arthritis and a photosensitive rash on her cheeks, given its characteristic presentation involving these symptoms.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with a rash that has developed over the past few days. On examination, you observe multiple lesions with concentric rings resembling a target or iris. These lesions are primarily on his hands and forearms, and he reports a recent history of a cold sore outbreak. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Erythema multiforme

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Target (iris) lesions are characteristic of erythema multiforme, a condition often triggered by infections or medications, presenting with concentric rings of varying colors.

questions.text: A patient presents with seven irregular hyperpigmented macules on the trunk and multiple small hyperpigmented macules in the axillae and groins since early childhood. There are no other skin lesions. Which is the most likely investigation to support the diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Slit-lamp examination of eye for Lisch nodules

questions.correct_answer: A. Slit-lamp examination of eye for Lisch nodules
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Slit-lamp examination of eye for Lisch nodules

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of multiple café-au-lait spots and axillary freckling is highly suggestive of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). The slit-lamp examination of the eye for Lisch nodules is the most appropriate investigation to support the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is being evaluated for seizures and developmental delay. During the examination, the physician notes multiple skin lesions suggestive of adenoma sebaceum and performs a detailed review of systems and imaging studies to identify associated conditions. Which of the following is NOT typically seen in the boy with the most likely diagnosis possible with the above clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Iris Nodule

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Iris nodules are not typically seen in tuberous sclerosis. This condition is characterized by renal cortical cysts, cardiac rhabdomyomas, and shagreen patches, among other manifestations.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents to the pediatric clinic with signs of malnutrition, including a distended abdomen, muscle wasting, and changes in skin and hair. On examination, the child's skin appears dry and has a characteristic appearance as shown in the image below. You suspect a nutritional deficiency as the underlying cause. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this appearance of the skin?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Kwashiorkor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "flaky paint" appearance of the skin is a characteristic sign of kwashiorkor, a form of severe malnutrition caused by protein deficiency.

questions.text: A patient with a history of persistent and refractory skin lesions presents to the oncology clinic. The oncologist considers total skin electron irradiation (TSEI) as a treatment option. For which of the following conditions is TSEI used?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mycosis Fungoides

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Total Skin Electron Irradiation (TSEI) is primarily used for the treatment of mycosis fungoides, the most common type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. It allows for effective treatment of widespread skin lesions while minimizing exposure to deeper tissues.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with a rash. Upon examination, you notice that the rash has a distinctive pattern and distribution. Considering her age and the appearance of the skin condition, you are evaluating her for possible underlying internal malignancy. Which of the following skin conditions is LEAST likely to be associated with underlying internal malignancy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Granuloma annulare

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Granuloma annulare is a benign skin condition not typically associated with underlying internal malignancies, unlike acanthosis nigricans, necrolytic migratory erythema, and erythema gyratum repens.

questions.text: A young female presents with a history of fever and nodular lesions over the shin. Histopathology reveals foamy histiocytes with neutrophilic infiltration. There is no evidence of vasculitis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Erythema nodosum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Erythema nodosum is characterized by tender, erythematous nodules with histopathology showing panniculitis with neutrophilic infiltration and foamy histiocytes without vasculitis. This aligns with the clinical presentation and histopathological findings described in the scenario.
